repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
* `Special` for `@markup.raw`
* `Structure` for `@markup.environment`
* derive `@markup.quote` and `@markup.math` from `@markup.raw`
* highlight `@markup.link.label` as `Underlined` as well (looks weird if everything but the label is underlined, and otherwise the link is invisible if concealed, as in LSP hover docs).

followup to #27067 

@echasnovski

comment_regular_data.body:
Two questions:
- Why use `Special` for `@markup.raw`? This is used both for `@markup.raw` and `@markup.raw.block` which are inline and block code. I am pretty sure that using `Comment` for both of them is the most expected and accepted highlighting.
- Is it a bad idea to link `@markup.environment` to `@module` directly? I'd say they are semantically similar enough to have them linked.

>  I am pretty sure that using Comment for both of them is the most expected and accepted highlighting.

I would disagree with that: most colorschemes have comments muted (and possibly italic), while inline code is very important and should stand out (or at least be on equal footing).

> Is it a bad idea to link @markup.environment to @module directly?

I don't think we've done that so far (except for "these are really the same but not in a suitable hierarchy"). And I'm not sure I agree; LaTeX environments have nothing to do with "modules" in the sense of programming languages (in fact, LaTeX has little to do with programming languages, period...)

> I would disagree with that: most colorschemes have comments muted (and possibly italic), while inline code is very important and should stand out (or at least be on equal footing).

I can see the point but not entirely convinced right now. Need a good night sleep on this.

Do you have the same opinion (that it should stand out with `Special`) about block code? Like inside ```` ``` ```` in markdown?

> I don't think we've done that so far (except for "these are really the same but not in a suitable hierarchy"). And I'm not sure I agree; LaTeX environments have nothing to do with "modules" in the sense of programming languages (in fact, LaTeX has little to do with programming languages, period...)

Yes, adding such semantically connected highlight links to `@` groups was a part of what I wanted to do as a follow up.

To me, `@module` is more like a core group for everything "namespace-like" or "structure-like", that is "something that encapsulates other, smaller, parts". With `markup.environment` falling into this category (at least based on the the term itself and description from [here](https://texfaq.org/FAQ-whatenv)).

> Do you have the same opinion (that it should stand out with Special) about block code? Like inside ``` in markdown?

Oh, my, yes. I feel quite strongly that inline/block code should **not** be Comment-like. (This will also apply to the default colorscheme, mind you.) It doesn't have to be `Special`, but that's the best core group I could find.

Anything else I don't feel as strongly about; I'm fine with linking to `@module` but then will leave it up to you if you intend to make more such changes.

> Oh, my, yes. I feel quite strongly that inline/block code should **not** be Comment-like. (This will also apply to the default colorscheme, mind you.) It doesn't have to be `Special`, but that's the best core group I could find.

The other option would be to define them directly with `Nvim{Light,Dark}Grey3` color which is roughly in the middle of `Comment` and `Normal`. But it doesn't stand out *that* much compared to `Normal`.

Let me try `Special` for code blocks for a (couple of) day(s).

So after spending some time with non-`Comment` `@text.literal` / `@markup.raw`, I can see the appeal. Plus my research of other Neovim and Helix color schemes do show that *most* of color schemes prefer colorful code text (both inline and block).

Picking from available groups, `Special` does seem to be the best choice.

I have a question about `@markup.math` and `@markup.quote`. What do you think about linking them both to either `@string.special` or `@character.special`? They look like a good fit semantically.

> I have a question about @markup.math and @markup.quote. What do you think about linking them both to either @string.special or @character.special? They look like a good fit semantically.

Hmm, not really a fan, since they can apply to large chunks of text -- that definitely rules out `@character.special`. And `@string.special` applies to "special strings like dates", which doesn't really seem to fit.

So I'd leave `@markup.math` as is (it's basically "raw TeX code") but agree that something else may make more sense for `@markup.quote` (which I haven't seen in the wild), possibly even `Comment`.

> So I'd leave `@markup.math` as is (it's basically "raw TeX code") but agree that something else may make more sense for `@markup.quote` (which I haven't seen in the wild), possibly even `Comment`.

Judging purely semantically, `@string.special` seems like the closest choice as both `@markup.math` and `@markup.quote` are... special strings inside markup.
As this seems more closely related to LaTeX than anything else, it will be better to trust your judgement on this.

I stand firm on `@markup.math` (which are just like code blocks or interpolations), but I am open for `@markup.quote`. I don't really think `@string` makes sense in the context of Markdown, tho...

If anything, this is an argument for treating `@markup` groups as new first-class standard groups, as they cover situations that are just not considered in any of the other groups. No link really makes sense (beyond some implicit fallbacks).

Would it be clearer to define `@markup` as `Special` and let the implicit fallback cover `math`, `raw`, etc.? This would have the same observable effect (some -- not obviously wrong (IMO) -- highlighting by default) without documenting this as the "right" semantic color?

> Would it be clearer to define `@markup` as `Special` and let the implicit fallback cover `math`, `raw`, etc.? This would have the same observable effect (some -- not obviously wrong (IMO) -- highlighting by default) without documenting this as the "right" semantic color?

I don't think making `@markup` `Special` is a good choice here. Judging by previous name (`@text`) and assumed usage, all `@markup.xxx` groups are expected to be used in some sort of plain text scenarios. So I'd say leaving it cleared or link to `Normal` (or define to only have `Normal` foreground) is more appropriate here. Having only `@markup.raw` as `Special` makes more sense to me, as it *is* a "special type of markup" with the most significant usage among other subgroups.

I do agree that default color scheme should define fewer of non-first level `@groups`. For example, right now color schemes need to explicitly define some of them and can not rely on the fallback. Example: most of `@keyword.xxx` groups will not fallback to `@keyword` if color scheme doesn't define them, as there are default link in default color scheme. But that's outside of this PR's scope.

`@markup` is never used in isolation (that group doesn't exist officially); the old `@text` was replaced with `@none`. (`@markup` is... Special in this way.) The `@markup` groups are for actual marked-up objects that should stand out from plain text (otherwise they wouldn't be marked up).

I will make that change (and add a comment to that effect in the file).
Yeah, let's go with the state of 6b8f747c89f243eb3abaecf0df7ce01cd0ec57d5 right now. I'll propose more changes in the default color scheme follow up PR.

Sure; that's not to preempt better choices for the default colorscheme, just some basic default links so people have somewhat reasonable treesitter highlights out of the box. (I _will_ have some opinions on that, though ;))

title: fix(treesitter): update `@markup` default links
